rev.diff:
Line 110: Line 110:
Rafsanjani's resignation from the Assembly caused concern among the opposition protesters, as they had been hoping that he would "help influence Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei to moderate his support for Mr. Ahmadinejad". Analysts have stated that his resignation allows the Assembly to choose a new supreme leader that will be more conservative than would otherwise have been possible.<ref name="Critic"/>
Rafsanjani's resignation from the Assembly caused concern among the opposition protesters, as they had been hoping that he would "help influence Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei to moderate his support for Mr. Ahmadinejad". Analysts have stated that his resignation allows the Assembly to choose a new supreme leader that will be more conservative than would otherwise have been possible.<ref name="Critic"/>

[[International Women's Day]] Marches were announced for the Day.

International Women's Day Marches were announced for the Day.
 
==Arrests==
==Arrests==
[[Ignacio PÃ©rez-Cambra]], the [[Consul (representative)|Consul]] of [[Spain]] in Iran, was arrested for a period of four hours during the early part of the day on 14 February. He was accused by Iranian police of going to one of the demonstrations.<ref>{{cite news |title=Detenido durante cuatro horas el cÃ³nsul de EspaÃ±a en IrÃ¡n |author=Angeles Espinosa |url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/internacional/Detenido/durante/horas/consul/Espana/Iran/elpepuint/20110214elpepuint_10/Tes |newspaper=[[El Pais]] |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref> Spain later demanded an explanation or apology from the Iranian government about the arrest of PÃ©rez-Cambra that included a "satisfactory response", threatening to call him home from Iran if one was not received. The foreign ministry already announced that it had "suspended an upcoming visit to Madrid by a senior Iranian diplomat." The UK also echoed its displeasure over the detainment of Cambra.<ref>{{cite news |title=Madrid demands Iran apologize for Spanish diplomat's arrest |author= |url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/politics/2011/02/15/madrid-demands-iran-apologize-spanish-diplomats-arrest/ |newspaper=[[Fox News]] |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=February 11, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Spain, UK protest to Iran over diplomat's detention |author=Adrian Croft |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/17/us-iran-spain-idUSTRE71G5HF20110217 |newspaper=[[Reuters]] |date=February 17, 2011 |accessdate=February 19, 2011}}</ref> Iran's [[Foreign Affairs Minister of Iran|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] [[Ali Akbar Salehi]] called the Spanish [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation (Spain)|Foreign Affairs Minister]] [[Trinidad JimÃ©nez]] on February 17 in order to apologize for the incident with Cambra, stating that those responsible for his arrest had been "unaware that they were violating the [[Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations|Vienna Convention]]", but that an investigation was underway nonetheless.<ref>{{cite news |title=Spain accepts Iranian apology for "diplomatic incident" |author= |url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/politics/2011/02/18/spain-accepts-iranian-apology-diplomatic-incident/ |newspaper=[[Fox News]] |date=February 18, 2011 |accessdate=February 19, 2011}}</ref>
[[Ignacio PÃ©rez-Cambra]], the [[Consul (representative)|Consul]] of [[Spain]] in Iran, was arrested for a period of four hours during the early part of the day on 14 February. He was accused by Iranian police of going to one of the demonstrations.<ref>{{cite news |title=Detenido durante cuatro horas el cÃ³nsul de EspaÃ±a en IrÃ¡n |author=Angeles Espinosa |url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/internacional/Detenido/durante/horas/consul/Espana/Iran/elpepuint/20110214elpepuint_10/Tes |newspaper=[[El Pais]] |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref> Spain later demanded an explanation or apology from the Iranian government about the arrest of PÃ©rez-Cambra that included a "satisfactory response", threatening to call him home from Iran if one was not received. The foreign ministry already announced that it had "suspended an upcoming visit to Madrid by a senior Iranian diplomat." The UK also echoed its displeasure over the detainment of Cambra.<ref>{{cite news |title=Madrid demands Iran apologize for Spanish diplomat's arrest |author= |url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/politics/2011/02/15/madrid-demands-iran-apologize-spanish-diplomats-arrest/ |newspaper=[[Fox News]] |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=February 11, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Spain, UK protest to Iran over diplomat's detention |author=Adrian Croft |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/17/us-iran-spain-idUSTRE71G5HF20110217 |newspaper=[[Reuters]] |date=February 17, 2011 |accessdate=February 19, 2011}}</ref> Iran's [[Foreign Affairs Minister of Iran|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] [[Ali Akbar Salehi]] called the Spanish [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation (Spain)|Foreign Affairs Minister]] [[Trinidad JimÃ©nez]] on February 17 in order to apologize for the incident with Cambra, stating that those responsible for his arrest had been "unaware that they were violating the [[Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations|Vienna Convention]]", but that an investigation was underway nonetheless.<ref>{{cite news |title=Spain accepts Iranian apology for "diplomatic incident" |author= |url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/politics/2011/02/18/spain-accepts-iranian-apology-diplomatic-incident/ |newspaper=[[Fox News]] |date=February 18, 2011 |accessdate=February 19, 2011}}</ref>
